Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating Stem Elongation as a Means to Increase Crop Productivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
As sessile organisms, plants need to effectively sense and respond to their environment in order to survive. One way they accomplish this is through the perception and response to light. A key group of proteins involved in modulating light-mediated responses are the AHLs, a group of DNA-binding proteins that influence stem elongation in seedlings. Stem elongation is among the first crucial steps in plant development for many crop plants. As the climate continues to change, it is increasingly important for us to gain a better understanding of how stem elongation is controlled, as it will facilitate the improvement of crop varieties that can cope with such changes. This EAPSI fellowship will enable further investigation into the role AHLs play in stem elongation, and how this elongation is further regulated by plant hormones. This research will be conducted at the RIKEN Institute under the direction of Dr. Keiko Sugimoto, a leading expert in plant cell research.

Using Arabidopsis as a model system, the overarching goal of this research is to understand how light mediates seedling growth. One key group of genes involved in this process is the AT-HOOK MOTIF NUCLEAR LOCALIED (AHL) gene family. AHL29/SUPRESSOR OF PHYTOCHROME B-4 (SOB3) directly regulates the auxin-associated genes YUCCA8 (YUC8) and members of the SMALL AUXIN UP RNA 19 (SAUR19) subfamily during seedling development. SOB3 is able to modulate hypocotyl elongation in seedlings, at least in part, by repressing transcription of the aforementioned genes. Since YUC8 and members of the SAUR19 subfamily are directly involved in phytohormone pathways, ChIP-Seq will be used to test the hypothesis that SOB3 binds to the promoters of additional genes associated with plant-specific hormone pathways, such as gibberellic acid, cytokinins, and jasmonic acid. Additionally, hypocotyl elongation assays will be performed using sob mutants and the aforementioned hormones to further investigate these interactions.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As sessile organisms, plants need a complex set of systems to turn external signals into internal cues. The factors that they respond to are expansive, and include but are not limited to: water, salinity, temperature, and light. External signals, such as light, are used by plants as an energy source and as a way to sense and respond to their current environment. In turn, the plant will trigger internal signals, such as those transmitted through plant hormones, to regulate growth and development. Arabidopsis thaliana has a short reproductive time and small seedlings, making it an extremely useful model system to study responses to light (photomorphogenesis). Utilizing Arabidopsis, we are trying to understand how light mediates seedling growth.

One key group of genes involved in photomorphogensis is the 29-member AT-HOOK MOTIF NUCLEAR LOCALIED (AHL) gene family. AHL family members are involved in a wide array of plant processes, including hypocotyl elongation. SOB3/AHL29 has been shown to regulate hypocotyl elongation in response to light. When SOB3 is overexpressed, hypocotyl elongation is repressed in light-grown seedlings, but not dark-grown seedlings (Zhao et al., 2013).

The research objective during my EAPSI Fellowship was to elucidate the suite of genes that SOB3 is interacting with, namely in hormone pathways, which would illuminate its role in light-mediated hypocotyl development. We were able to accomplish this goal by using a novel technique, ChIP-Seq, in Dr. Sugimoto’s lab at the RIKEN Center for Sustainable Research Science (CSRS). This experiment has revealed dozens of interesting targets of SOB3, which will be included in subsequent manuscripts and as part of my Ph.D. dissertation. Furthermore, these data will aid in the continuation of my Ph.D. research, including another novel technique called Hi-C Seq. While ChIP-Seq has shown the genome-wide targets of SOB3, Hi-C Seq will allow us to map the 3D interactions of SOB3 within the genome.

The research at RIKEN will not only contribute to publications and my Ph.D. dissertation, it will also aid in the effort to increase crop yield. Research on the AHL family of genes in the Neff Lab is in partly funded by USDA-NIFA in an effort to improve the production of crop plants. Hypocotyl elongation is an important aspect of crop yield and is also being studied in the oil seed plant Camelina. Research on the AHLs in Arabidopsis may compliment the research in Camelina, since the AHLs belong to a conserved family of genes. Moreover, HMGA proteins, which contain the same type of DNA-binding domain as the AHL proteins, have also been implicated in many human cancers. Therefore, the research conducted at RIKEN could help in the effort to improve crop yield and may also shed light on human disease pathways.

Finally, the research performed at RIKEN has furthered the collaboration between the Sugimoto Lab and the Neff Lab, which was established by Dr. David Favero as an EAPSI fellow. It has also afforded me an extremely valuable opportunity to establish my own personal connections with Japanese scientists while gaining international experience.
